title: New York hotel launches EMOJI room service for lazy guests
text:
New York hotel launches EMOJI room service for lazy guests New York hotel launches EMOJI room service for lazy guests IF YOU'RE too tired to talk, a new service lets you order food or cure your hangover with an Emoji message request. PUBLISHED: 12:45, Fri, Oct 23, 2015 | UPDATED: 12:58, Fri, Oct 23, 2015 GETTY The Aloft Manhattan Downtown hotel has launched a new room service menu 
Sometimes when you’re relaxing in a hotel room on your own, the last thing you want is actual human contact. 
So if you’re desperate for some room service but can’t face the prospect of speaking to an actual person, a New York hotel has got you covered. Related articles Magaluf's not just heavy drinking and sex games, says new Mayor 
The Aloft Manhattan Downtown hotel has just launched its Text it, Get it service, that allows you to request room services with just an emoji text. 
Guests have a menu of six package options to choose from. There’s “The Hangover”, which consists of two bottles of water, painkillers and two bananas. PR This is the menu, from which people order room service via their phones PR A room in the The Aloft Manhattan Downtown hotel launched its Text it, Get it service 
“The Munchies” brings junk food like Snickers and Coke cans right to your door. “The Sightseer” offers guests a Metrocard, a city map and two drinks. 
“The Phone Charger” provides you with whatever charger you may need for your mobile device. 
If guests are in need of a little freshen up, there’s "The Re:Fresh”, which brings you toothpaste, a toothbrush, a razor and deodorant. 
And for the more daring guests, you can order the “Surprise Me” option, treating you to a mystery gift of ‘fun swag and cool stuff’. 
This is not a new concept though. Fooji created a service that allows you to order food in New York, Chicago and San Francisco with emojis. And in June this year, Dominoes allowed customers to tweet their order with a pizza emoji. 
Paige Francis, vice president of the hotel's global brand management group, said: "Emojis are ubiquitous right now – everyone I know uses them both in personal and professional communications, so why shouldn’t our guests be able to use them when once they step into our hotels? 
"And, frankly, emojis are just fun.” Related articles
